venerable: Profoundly honored, especially due to age, wisdom, or character.
vindicate: To clear from accusation, blame, suspicion, or doubt with supporting proof.
wary: Marked by keen caution and watchful prudence.
zealous: Marked by active interest and enthusiasm.
affable: Friendly, pleasant, and easy to talk to.
altruistic: Showing unselfish concern for the welfare of others.
arduous: Difficult to accomplish; requiring great effort.
belligerent: Characteristic of an enemy or one eager to fight.
candor: The quality of being honest and straightforward.
catalyst: Something that causes an important event to happen.
charlatan: A person falsely claiming to have special knowledge or skill.
circumspect: Careful to consider potential consequences and avoid risk.
clandestine: Conducted with or marked by hidden aims or methods.
commiserate: To feel or express sympathy or compassion.
copious: Large in number or quantity; abundant.
debacle: A sudden and complete failure; a fiasco.
decadent: Marked by excessive self-indulgence and moral decay.
deft: Skillful in physical movements; especially of the hands.
disparage: To express a negative opinion of.
docile: Easily handled or managed; willing to be taught or led.
eloquent: Expressing yourself readily, clearly, and effectively.
enthrall: To capture the fascinated attention of.
eradicate: To destroy completely; to put an end to.
esoteric: Intended for or understood by only a select few.
fastidious: Giving careful attention to detail; hard to please.
fluctuate: To rise and fall irregularly in number or amount.
futile: Incapable of producing any useful result.
idiosyncrasy: A behavior or way of thought peculiar to an individual.
ignominious: Deserving or causing public disgrace or shame.
impeccable: In accordance with the highest standards; faultless.
indolent: Wanting to avoid activity or exertion; lazy.
inept: Having or showing no skill; clumsy.
infallible: Incapable of making mistakes or being wrong.
languid: Displaying or having a disinclination for physical exertion.
magnanimous: Very generous or forgiving, especially toward a rival or less powerful person.
malevolent: Wishing or appearing to wish evil to others.
melancholy: A feeling of pensive sadness, typically with no obvious cause.
meticulous: Showing great attention to detail; very careful and precise.
oblivious: Not aware of or not concerned about what is happening.
obsolete: No longer produced or used; out of date.
panacea: A solution or remedy for all problems or difficulties.
paragon: A person or thing regarded as a perfect example of a quality.
pensive: Engaged in deep or serious thought.
placate: To make someone less angry or hostile.
quell: To put an end to, typically by force.
rancor: Bitterness or resentfulness, especially when long-standing.
recalcitrant: Having an obstinately uncooperative attitude toward authority.
relinquish: To voluntarily cease to keep or claim; give up.
remorse: Deep regret or guilt for a wrong committed.
resilient: Able to withstand or recover quickly from difficult conditions.
reverence: Deep respect for someone or something.
sagacious: Having or showing keen mental discernment and good judgment.
scrupulous: Diligent, thorough, and extremely attentive to details.
skeptical: Not easily convinced; having doubts or reservations.
spontaneous: Performed or occurring as a result of a sudden impulse.
spurious: Not being what it purports to be; false or fake.
stoic: Enduring pain and hardship without showing feelings or complaining.
submissive: Ready to conform to the authority or will of others.
superfluous: Unnecessary, especially through being more than enough.
tenacious: Tending to keep a firm hold of something; persistent.
transient: Lasting only for a short time; impermanent.
trepidation: A feeling of fear or agitation about something that may happen.
usurp: Take (a position of power) illegally or by force.
vacuous: Having or showing a lack of thought or intelligence.
vex: To make someone feel annoyed, frustrated, or worried.
vindictive: Having or showing a strong desire for revenge.
volatile: Liable to change rapidly and unpredictably.
wheedle: To use flattery or coaxing in order to persuade.
whimsical: Playfully quaint or fanciful, especially in an appealing way.
wry: Using or expressing dry, especially mocking, humor.
zenith: The time at which something is most powerful or successful.
abet: To encourage or assist someone to do something wrong.
acumen: The ability to make good judgments and quick decisions.
aplomb: Self-confidence or assurance, especially in a demanding situation.
avarice: Extreme greed for wealth or material gain.
blandishment: A flattering or pleasing statement used to persuade.
calumny: The making of false and defamatory statements to damage someone’s reputation.
capitulate: Cease to resist an opponent; surrender.
chicanery: The use of trickery to achieve a political, financial, or legal purpose.
circuitous: Longer than the most direct way.
cogitate: To think deeply about something; meditate or reflect.
conundrum: A confusing and difficult problem or question.
diatribe: A forceful and bitter verbal attack against someone or something.
